_source.content:
, 6:58 PM   
OKLAHOMA CITY — Much of the buzz around the Oklahoma City Thunder has been about Kevin Durant’s return. 
 
Serge Ibaka’s comeback is nearly as important. The three-time member of the All-Defence first team and two-time league blocks leader missed the final month last season while recovering from knee surgery and, without him, Oklahoma City’s defence tanked. 
 
In 64 games with Ibaka, the Thunder allowed 99.9 points per game. In 18 games without him, Oklahoma City surrendered 108.3 points. The Thunder went 10-8 during that final stretch and missed the playoffs. 
 
Now the 6-foot-10 power forward who Durant calls the key to their success has been cleared to play. Thunder general manager Sam Presti says Ibaka might not play every preseason game, but that’s normal for the top players.
_source.title: Ibaka’s return dhould boost Oklahoma City defence

_source.content:
Tampa Bay Buccaneers wide receiver Mike Evans was held out of practice Monday due to his injured hamstring. He also missed the final two preseason games. Evans is expected to return to practice later this week and be ready to start the season opener. However, hamstrings do tend to linger. This is a situation worth keeping a close eye on. 

FANTASY ANALYSIS: The Bucs desperately need Evans on the field against the Titans. It's a winnable game and they need their best player out there. Evans presence is obviously a...
_source.title: Buccaneers WR Mike Evans held out of practice Monday

_source.content: Trent Richardson's NFL career is probably over. The running back was cut by the Oakland Raiders on Monday, according to multiple reports. In addition to Richardson's release, four players with ties to the state of Oregon were also released as teams reduce their rosters to 75 players. Former Oregon Ducks linebacker Josh Kaddu was cut by the Minnesota Vikings and former Oregon State Beavers tight end Connor Hamlett was released by the Jacksonville Jaguars. Former Ducks tight end David Paulson was cut by the San Diego Chargers and former Beavers safety Ty Zimmerman was waived by the Seattle Seahawks. Richardson, selected third overall by Cleveland in the 2012 NFL draft, signed a two-year, $3.85 million deal - $600,000 guaranteed - with the Raiders in March. Richardson struggled during training camp and failed to beat out other running backs during the preseason. He had gained just 42 yards on 18 carries during three preseason games.   The Browns traded Richardson to the Indianapolis Colts in 2014, but his time with the Colts was a disaster, where he benched during the final games of the 2014 regular season and released in March. Richardson, 25, is still young, but it's hard to imagine another team taking a chance of him. Don't feel too bad for Richardson, he's still owed more than $3 million from the Colts this season. -- Geoffrey C. Arnold | @geoffreyCarnold
_source.title: Oakland Raiders cut Trent Richardson; four former Ducks, Beavers players also released

_source.content: Trent Richardson's NFL career is probably over. The running back was cut by the Oakland Raiders on Monday, according to multiple reports. In addition to Richardson's release, four players with ties to the state of Oregon were also released as teams reduce their rosters to 75 players. Former Oregon Ducks linebacker Josh Kaddu was cut by the Minnesota Vikings and former Oregon State Beavers tight end Connor Hamlett was released by the Jacksonville Jaguars. Former Ducks tight end David Paulson was cut by the San Diego Chargers and former Beavers safety Ty Zimmerman was waived by the Seattle Seahawks. Richardson, selected third overall by Cleveland in the 2012 NFL draft, signed a two-year, $3.85 million deal - $600,000 guaranteed - with the Raiders in March. Richardson struggled during training camp and failed to beat out other running backs during the preseason. He had gained just 42 yards on 18 carries during three preseason games.   The Browns traded Richardson to the Indianapolis Colts in 2014, but his time with the Colts was a disaster, where he benched during the final games of the 2014 regular season and released in March. Richardson, 25, is still young, but it's hard to imagine another team taking a chance of him. Don't feel too bad for Richardson, he's still owed more than $3 million from the Colts this season. -- Geoffrey C. Arnold | @geoffreyCarnold
_source.title: Oakland Raiders cut Trent Richardson; four former Ducks, Beavers players also released

_source.content:
Post-game notes courtesy of the NYR: 
 

 
  
 
  
 
  
 
Flyers 5, Rangers 3. 
 
Click here for boxscore with links to Game Summary, etc. 
 

 
–        TEAM EFFORT – Six different Rangers registered a point in tonight’s game. Through two preseason games, 13 different Rangers have recorded a point and six different Blueshirts have tallied a goal. 
 
–        DEUCES WILD – The Rangers have tallied two goals in four of six periods through two preseason games this season. 
 
–        SECOND TO NONE – The Blueshirts recorded two goals in the second period of tonight’s contest, and they outshot the Flyers, 15-7, in the second period. In their first two preseason games, New York has recorded four goals and has outshot its opponent, 25-12, in the second period. 
 
–        HOT AT THE DOT – New York won 33 of 62 faceoffs (53.2%) in tonight’s contest, including 11 of 19 faceoffs in the offensive zone (57.9%). Each of the six Rangers who took a faceoff in the game posted a faceoff win percentage of 50% or higher. In two preseason games, the Rangers have won 63 of 118 faceoffs (53.4%). 
 
–        HITTING MACHINE – The Rangers were credited with 31 hits in the game. Thirteen different Blueshirts were credited with at least one hit in the contest, while seven Rangers tied for the team-high with three hits apiece. 
 

 
–        Mat Bodie registered two goals, led all Rangers with five shots on goal, and posted a plus-two rating in 21:29 of ice time. In 2014-15, Bodie led AHL rookie defensemen in assists (27) and tied for first among AHL rookie defensemen in points (32) while playing with the Hartford Wolf Pack. He also led Hartford defensemen in games played (75), assists, and plus/minus rating (plus-11), ranked second in points, and tied for third in goals (five) last season. 
 
–        Oscar Lindberg tallied two points (one goal, one assist), recorded three shots on goal, and posted a plus-two rating. Lindberg has registered a goal/point in each of the Rangers’ first two preseason games this year (two goals, one assist), and he has also posted a plus-two rating in each preseason contest. He recorded 56 points (28 goals, 28 assists) with the Wolf Pack last season, including 20 points (12 goals, eight assists) in his last 19 regular season games. In addition, Lindberg notched 16 points (three goals, 13 assists) in 15 playoff contests with Hartford last season. 
 
–        Viktor Stalberg tallied an assist, tied for the team-high with three hits, and posted a plus-one rating in 15:47 of ice time. Stalberg has recorded a point in each of the Blueshirts’ first two preseason games this year (one goal, one assist), and he has also registered a plus-one rating and three hits in each preseason contest. Entering the 2015-16 season, he has registered 127 of his 132 career NHL points at even strength. 
 
–        Kevin Klein recorded an assist, tied for the game-high with three blocked shots, and posted a plus-one rating in 21:34 of ice time. Klein has tallied an assist/point in each of the Rangers’ first two preseason games, registering four assists in the two contests. Prior to suffering an injury on Mar. 11, 2015, Klein led Rangers defensemen in goals (nine), points (26), plus/minus rating (plus-24), and game-winning goals (four) in 2014-15. 
 
–        Richard Nejezchleb notched an assist, recorded two shots on goal, and posted a plus-one rating in the contest. Nejezchleb registered 51 points (20 goals, 31 assists) in 49 games with the Brandon Wheat Kings and the Tri-City Americans of the Western Hockey League (WHL) last season. 
 
–        Luke Adam tallied an assist, recorded three shots on goal, was credited with two hits, and won six of 12 faceoffs (50%) in the game. In 2014-15, Adam registered 16 goals and 26 assists for 42 points in 73 AHL games with the Rochester Americans and the Springfield Falcons. 
 
  
 
Photo by Getty Images . 
 
Click here to go to @RangersReport on Twitter. 
 
  
 
  
 
The post Flyers 5, Rangers 3 … post-game notes appeared first on Rangers Report .
_source.title: Flyers 5, Rangers 3 … post-game notes

_source.content:
ASHBURN, Va. — Redskins quarterback Robert Griffin III is still awaiting medical clearance to return from a concussion he sustained three weeks ago. 
 
Griffin or Colt McCoy will back up starter Kirk Cousins on Sunday when Washington opens its season against the Miami Dolphins. 
 
Coach Jay Gruden said Thursday he has "no idea" why the team has yet to receive a written response from the independent neurologist who examined Griffin this week. On Wednesday, he said he expected to receive it by the end of the day. 
 
Gruden suggested he could wait until game day to announce Washington’s backup. 
 
Griffin lost his starting job to Cousins early last week and has missed Washington's final two preseason games. Gruden had named Griffin this season's starter in February.
_source.title: RGIII still awaiting medical clearance to return

_source.content:
Updated at 4:07 p.m. ET 
 
If Friday's roster move is any indication, Tim Tebow might be an Eagle in 2015.  
 
Philadelphia traded Matt Barkley, with whom Tebow had been battling for the third-string quarterback role, to Arizona for a conditional late-round draft pick, Fox Sports was first to report . It's a seventh-round pick, according to ESPN , and the Eagles get it if Barkley is on the roster for six games.  
 
 MORE: Each team's most indispensable non-QB | NFL roster cut schedule   
 
Barkley was on Philly's roster bubble , as the Eagles were expected to keep either him or Tebow. Coach Chip Kelly alternated between the two in Thursday's final preseason game against the Jets, letting each play one quarter.
_source.title: Eagles trade Matt Barkley to Cardinals, reports say

_source.content:
JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- The Jacksonville Jaguars have signed eight players, including two final-round draft picks, to their practice squad. 
 
The Jaguars added both of their seventh-round picks from the 2015 draft, receiver Neal Sterling and tight end Ben Koyack. Sterling missed the first three games of the preseason with a hamstring injury. Koyack was the odd-man out when general manager Dave Caldwell decided to keep four tight ends on the active roster. 
 
Jacksonville also signed defensive lineman Richard Ash, safety Craig Loston, offensive lineman Chris Reed, linebacker Todd Thomas, cornerback Peyton Thompson and receiver Tony Washington to the practice squad. 
 
The Jaguars also planned to sign quarterback Stephen Morris to the practice squad, but Philadelphia claimed Morris off waivers. They have two spots open on the squad. 
 
___ 
 
AP NFL website: www.pro32.ap.org and www.twitter.com/AP_NFL
_source.title: Jaguars sign 8, including 2 draft picks, to practice squad
